米尔顿·弗里德曼在阿根廷可能下一任总统的个人和政治生活中占据重要地位。哈维尔·米雷 (Javier Milei) 的想法受到了 20 世纪最著名的自由市场经济学家的启发，这些想法使他在 8 月份的国家初选中意外获胜。弗里德曼影响了米莱先生关于国家理想规模（微小）及其在经济中的作用（不存在）的观点。米莱先生的钦佩之情如此之深，以至于他以弗里德曼的名字命名了他的四只宠物獒犬中的一只。这位前经济学讲师在最近的一次采访中告诉《经济学人》 ，米尔顿和他的其他狗（所有这些狗都以经济学家的名字命名）组成了“世界上最好的战略委员会”。

米雷受弗里德曼影响的提议中影响最深远的就是经济美元化。这将涉及用美元取代比索，并意味着摆脱阿根廷央行，米莱称其为“宇宙中最糟糕的事情”。他夸大了，但只有一点点。阿根廷经济千疮百孔。年通货膨胀率为113%。央行已经耗尽了美元。自今年年初以来，比索兑美元的价值已减半。简而言之，激进思考的时代已经到来。不幸的是，美元化更有可能是一种诅咒，而不是阿根廷问题的解决方案。

当一个国家将其经济与另一个国家的货币挂钩时，它就放弃了制定自己的货币政策。利率将由美联储决定，这使得利率更加可预测，而且几乎不可能被篡改。对于像阿根廷这样历史记录如此坎坷的国家来说，这将缓解许多令人头疼的问题。无论如何，大多数阿根廷人都使用美元。正式宣布这种情况将使公众避免从美元到比索来回兑换的麻烦。作为世界上交易量最大的货币，美元的汇率不会因阿根廷这个规模相当小的经济体所发生的任何事情而受到影响，这意味着货币价值将不再上下波动。厄瓜多尔在 2000 年美元化之后，这个公式至少在一段时间内保持了相对稳定。

然而，主要的吸引力在于阿根廷将被禁止印钞。弗里德曼对中央银行持批评态度，认为大多数中央银行都太弱，无法控制通货膨胀，因为这样做意味着要坚定地顶住政客的压力，要求他们更容易支付账单或让经济在选举期间过热。正如米莱先生很快指出的那样，阿根廷央行是最不负责任的央行之一。美元化将使印刷机变得遥不可及。支持者认为，这意味着国家缩减规模和与通货膨胀的长期斗争结束只是时间问题。

然而，这一论点有一个问题：它对政府抱有不切实际的玫瑰色看法。它假设政客们意识到他们在危机中无法再向央行求助，他们会自动将借贷减少到安全水平。如果政府过度借贷的唯一原因是因为他们知道央行会救助他们，那么情况确实如此。事实上，大多数政府之所以举债，是因为面临着巨大的压力。贷款人需要偿还。官僚机构必须进行重组。反对党敦促现任者花钱。而且，最紧迫的是，选民开始期望国家提供某些服务。印刷机的缺乏并不足以消除这些担忧。

当灾难袭来时，美元化经济中的事情就会变得可怕。没有中央银行充当政府或银行系统的最后贷款人。因此，违约的可能性变得更大。本可以通过紧急流动性拯救的银行倒闭，政府缺乏美元来支付存款，导致数百万人陷入困境。此外，届时大部分借款可能会受到美国法律的管辖，从而使政府在任何重组谈判中处于不利地位。

事实上，厄瓜多尔目前正在经历美元化的许多弊端。政策一出台，物价立刻就稳定了。但它也未能遏制政府的财政赤字。此后，政策制定者采取了越来越有创意的方式来为该法案提供资金，推动该国于 2019 年与国际货币基金组织达成协议。

米莱，震撼

阿根廷陷入灾难的未来比政策制定者了解成功美元化所需的艰难决定的未来更容易预见。一个世纪以来的大部分时间里，财政过剩一直是一个问题。过去 65 年来，国际货币基金组织已对该国进行了 22 次救助，该基金已经筋疲力尽，以至于放弃了要求该国实现收支平衡的要求。一系列左翼政府建立了庞大的福利国家和庞大的官僚机构。米莱先生承诺向占GDP 38% 的公共部门削减 GDP的15%，但很难概述这些资金的来源。

还有很多其他问题。一个重要的问题是，米雷先生的政府将如何找到他的团队认为转向美元所需的 400 亿美元。目前，阿根廷甚至无法偿还国际货币基金组织的债务，该国欠国际货币基金组织 440 亿美元。由于美国货币耗尽，央行转而烧毁从中国借来的人民币。米雷先生建议通过离岸基金出售国有企业和政府债务，以筹集必要的资金。很难想象会有很多买家。

无论谁在 12 月掌权，都将处于一个糟糕的境地。忘记寻找资金来实现美元化吧。越来越多的经济学家认为，该国再次资不抵债，这意味着它几乎不可能偿还现有债务。该国的债券价格反映了金融市场正在消化另一次债务重组的事实。为了重新开始，阿根廷可能需要违约，而不是美元化。 ■

; Thu, 07 Sep 2023 10:18:51 GMT /内容/k6vajuj8m7r7qm737crfq4r32ctesoar https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/09/07/argentina-needs-to-default-not-dollarise Should you fix your mortgage for ever?

很少有资产像住房一样具有政治性，因此很少有市场像抵押贷款市场那样如此依赖国界。政府可以无休止地调整一切来控制事情的发展，涉及一切事情，从你可以借多少钱、谁可以贷，到如果你强硬他们可以做什么。然而，对于当今的借款人来说，一键拨号感觉最为紧迫：您的贷款期限是多长？

如果您是美国人或丹麦人，答案很可能是您在抵押贷款期间享有固定利率。因此，你可能对鹰派央行行长和债券收益率攀升的关注度很低。在许多其他国家，包括英国、加拿大和南欧大部分国家，抵押贷款利率往往最多固定几年，或者根本不固定。如果你属于这一类，那么你最近对货币政策的思考可能比你想要的要多得多，因为（恭喜！）你是货币政策的传导渠道之一。面对即将增加的付款，您可能会羡慕那些永远不需要担心的人。

然而，对于这个群体来说，事情并不像最初看上去那么美好。美国冻结的房地产市场，房主不愿出售并失去在廉价货币时期锁定的低利率，这应该提醒政策制定者注意长期修复的危险。对于抵押贷款付款人来说，有一个更直接的理由对此类贷款保持警惕。终生利率可能会提供心理安全。但你必须付出高昂的代价才能获得安全。

要了解原因，首先要从如何设置固定费率开始。无论是谁向你贷款——银行、建屋互助会或债券投资者——要么自己借钱（比如从储户那里），要么放弃借给其他人（比如通过购买政府债券）。在这两种情况下，他们都放弃了其他地方的利息支付。如果他们要放贷的话，你的抵押贷款利率需要补偿这一点。一种补偿方法是根据市场条件浮动的利率，始终与贷方在其他地方损失的利息支付相匹配。另一种是在一定年限内固定的利率，按照贷款人在此期间预期的平均融资成本。

问题是你可能想提前偿还抵押贷款——例如搬家。对于浮动利率，贷方不太可能介意。毕竟，他们可以拿走你的还款并将其借给其他人以获得相同的收入。但对于固定利率，他们可能会非常介意。假设您最初同意支付 5% 的利息，为期 30 年，然后想在同等市场利率降至 3% 时偿还。在这种情况下，您的贷方将无法再以相同的收入向您提供还款。同样，他们会想要补偿：两个百分点的差异，乘以抵押贷款的剩余年数，再乘以您的平均余额。换句话说，很多。

因此，30 年期固定利率在世界大部分地区并不受欢迎。如果情况发生变化并且市场朝着错误的方向发展，很少有借款人愿意承担巨额提前还款成本的风险。监管机构的一个解决方案是限制成本，但这首先会阻碍长期修复的贷款。

除此之外，美国和丹麦采用的替代解决方案看起来几乎就像炼金术一样。在这两个国家，抵押贷款的固定期限为 30 年，并可根据借款人的要求按面值提前偿还。无论利率如何变动，美国人都不会获得任何利润或损失。同样，如果利率下降，丹麦借款人也无需支付罚金（相比之下，固定利率变得昂贵），但如果利率上升，则可以实现利润。这意味着，与美国人不同，丹麦人不必担心放弃比市场更便宜的价格来搬家，而且可以更自由地这样做。

然而，一切都是有代价的，在这种情况下，这个代价就是高得令人瞠目结舌的借贷成本。新的 30 年期美国抵押贷款的平均利率为 7.2%，而 30 年期国债利率仅为 4.4%。在丹麦，相应的税率为 5.3% 和 2.9%。与此同时，在英国，抵押贷款持有人和政府的借贷成本大致相似。换句话说，这两项长期修复措施都使相关 360 个月抵押贷款还款额增加了三分之一以上。那些几年前拥有令人羡慕的远见以确保最低利率的人可能不会太介意。其他人，无论多么羡慕，都应该记住，安全并不便宜。 ■

; Thu, 07 Sep 2023 10:17:20 GMT /内容/fc9jihkd23694977ba2miodkvdpvq1mp https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/09/07/should-you-fix-your-mortgage-for-ever How Chicago school economists reshaped American justice

近年来，美国司法部反垄断部门一直在打击企业合并，提出了创纪录数量的投诉，试图阻止最大的企业变得更大。除了少数例外，这些努力都遭到了法院的阻挠。让法官干预商业如此困难，反映出芝加哥大学这一机构的工作，该机构因其对经济的自由市场影响力而不是法律而闻名。

五十年前的这个秋天，联邦法官、芝加哥学者理查德·波斯纳（Richard Posner）发表了他的《法律的经济分析》。该书现已出版第九版，引发了包括加里·贝克尔、罗纳德·科斯和米尔顿·弗里德曼在内的芝加哥学派经济学家的大量思想，这些思想进入了美国法官和律师的著作中。 “法律与经济”运动使法院更加理性和严谨。它还改变了法官的判决。研究发现，那些接触其想法的人更反对监管机构，不太可能执行反垄断法，并且往往会更频繁地判处监禁，时间也更长。

经济学与法律之间的联系长期以来一直被研究。托马斯·霍布斯在 1651 年出版的《利维坦》中写道，经济交换体系所需的安全产权是一种法律虚构，只在现代国家中出现。到了 19 世纪末，经济学家开始分析与经济学重叠的法律领域，例如税收问题。

随着法律和经济运动的到来，所有法律问题都突然在行为者的激励及其所产生的变化的背景下得到解决。在《犯罪与惩罚：一种经济方法》（1968）中，贝克尔认为，判决不是惩罚与改革机会之间的平衡行为，而是主要起到威慑作用：字面意思是“犯罪的代价”。他认为，严厉的判决可以减少犯罪活动，就像高价格减少需求一样。贝克尔警告说，更大的逮捕机会比更长的监禁更具威慑力，贝克尔的理论自此得到了数十年经验证据的证实。

太陡了？

耶鲁大学法学院前院长、该领域的另一位创始人吉多·卡拉布雷西 (Guido Calabresi) 回忆道，在该运动的早期，“法律学院很少关注我们的工作”。有两件事改变了这一点。第一本是波斯纳先生的畅销教科书，他在书中写道：“也许可以从经济理论中推导出法律本身的基本形式特征。”波斯纳先生是一位法学家，他的写作语言为其他法学家所熟悉。然而，他也深受芝加哥学派的经济见解的影响。他的书成功地将法律与经济学运动推向了法律主流。

第二个因素是一个名为曼恩联邦法官经济研究所的为期两周的项目，该项目从 1976 年持续到 1998 年。该项目由企业和保守派基金会资助，并在迈阿密的一家海滨酒店住宿，费用全免。然而，这并不是一个假期，尽管那些被昵称为“棕榈树上的帕累托”的人。课程要求极高，由弗里德曼和保罗·萨缪尔森等经济学家授课，他们都曾获得过诺贝尔奖。

到 20 世纪 90 年代初，近一半的联邦司法人员在迈阿密呆了几周。出席者包括两位未来的最高法院法官：克拉伦斯·托马斯（Clarence Thomas）（一位保守派人士）和露丝·巴德·金斯伯格（Ruth Bader Ginsburg）（他的自由派同行）。后来，金斯伯格应用曼恩计划倡导的所谓“消费者福利标准”，在反垄断案件上与保守派多数派一起投票，令同事们大吃一惊。这表明公司合并只有在提高价格或降低商品或服务质量的情况下才具有反竞争性。金斯伯格写道，她在迈阿密接受的指导“远比佛罗里达州的阳光强烈”。

在《经济学季刊》审阅的一篇论文中，苏黎世联邦理工学院的埃利奥特·阿什、普林斯顿大学的丹尼尔·陈和哥伦比亚大学的苏雷什·奈杜将曼恩计划视为一项自然实验，比较了每位校友在参加该计划之前和之后的决定。此次会议。然后，他们使用一种称为“词嵌入”的人工智能方法来评估超过一百万个巡回法院和地区法院案件中法官意见中的语言。

研究人员发现，在迈阿密工作一段时间后，联邦法官更有可能使用“效率”和“市场”等术语，而不太可能使用“解除”和“撤销”等术语。曼恩校友在参加培训后的几年里，对反垄断和其他经济案件采取作者所描述的“保守”立场的频率增加了 30%。他们判处监禁的频率也增加了 5%，刑期也延长了 25%。 2005 年之后，最高法院的一项裁决赋予联邦法官更大的量刑自由裁量权，这种影响变得更加强烈。

研究人员正在将经济分析的无情视角转向法律和经济学本身，这是一个充满希望的趋势。自芝加哥学派的全盛时期以来，这门令人沮丧的科学已经取得了长足的进步。在很大程度上要归功于行为经济学的经验主义，它不再那么执着于像完全理性的行动者这样的抽象概念。这软化了芝加哥学派的一些尖锐棱角。但法官仍需要时间来改变他们的做法。正如阿什先生指出的那样：“芝加哥学派的经济学家可能都已退休或去世，但曼恩校友仍然是司法部门的积极成员。”在美国各地的法庭上，波斯纳先生的影响力将持续数十年。 ■

巴厘岛，印度尼西亚的度假胜地， 和韩国港口釜山不容易混淆。前者生产的工业机械很少；后者生产的工业机械很少。后者无法适应全年的热带气候。但两者有一些共同点。这些地区属于亚洲地区，目前因中国经济重新开放效果不佳以及经济长期放缓的前景而面临危险。

过去二十年，许多亚洲国家受益于中国的增长，与世界第二大经济体紧密相连。由于中国正处于房地产低迷时期，今年前7个月房地产投资下降了9%，这些国家现在面临着头痛的问题。中国不再是他们商品的大买家了。 9月7日公布的数据显示，截至8月份全年进口下降7.3%。

在非洲大陆较富裕的地区，半导体电路和汽车零部件制造商正在承受亏损。 8月份韩国对华出口同比下降20%。 9 月 4 日，政府承诺提供新的支持，除了今年早些时候的税收减免和其他计划外，还宣布为出口商提供高达 181 万亿韩元（1,360 亿美元）的贷款。 1月至7月，台湾对中国大陆和香港的出口比去年同期下降了28%。高盛银行估计，中国国内生产总值的近 10% 是由中国大陆的消费和投资推动的。

一些出口商可能希望，由于全球电子产品销售放缓而加剧的中国经济衰退已经触底，因为进口同比下降已趋于稳定。但大多数人预计不会出现快速转变。韩国商工会议所最近公布了对302家向中国出口的国内企业的调查。近五分之四的人预计经济衰退将持续下去。如果中国政府没有采取更充分的刺激措施，如此低的期望很可能会实现。

在东南亚，游客人数尚未恢复到新冠疫情前的水平。 1 月至 7 月期间，泰国仅接待了 180 万名中国游客，而 2019 年则超过 1100 万人次。曼谷新政府上周宣布将放宽签证规定，以鼓励中国游客回国。该地区一些国家的旅游业规模足以影响其总体贸易平衡。在柬埔寨、老挝、马来西亚和泰国，2019 年（新冠疫情爆发之前）旅游业占出口总额的 9% 至 25%，其中中国是这四个国家的最大游客来源国。

Gavekal Research 的 Vincent Tsui 表示，印度、印度尼西亚和菲律宾等一些亚洲国家受经济放缓影响较小。它们的工业基础较小，这意味着它们在过去二十年中与中国建立的联系较少。徐先生认为，这种较低的风险敞口是今年各国货币兑美元表现更好的原因（见图表）。

即使在经济衰退期间，也并非一切都朝着同一个方向发展。泰国的榴莲出口商最近成为赢家。榴莲是一种辛辣的水果，在亚洲大部分地区莫名其妙地受欢迎。今年前7个月，中国水果进口量较去年同期增长了52%。泰国官员将这一繁荣归功于新的交通线路，特别是连接老挝和中国的火车线。可悲的是，对于亚洲其他地区来说，并不是每个人都是泰国榴莲种植者。 ■

; Thu, 07 Sep 2023 10:14:20 GMT /内容/30uhajfhh2s6jdv5fp7kab4sbopshahk https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/09/07/chinas-slowdown-is-ratdling-asian-economies The end of a remarkable era in Indian finance

大多数人会去伦敦、纽约或香港寻找世界上杰出的金融家。但也许孟买值得一看。毕竟，印度银行体系因 20 世纪 50 年代开始的一波社会主义实验浪潮而衰弱，而这里是三人的故乡，他们重建了印度银行体系。最后一位巨头 Uday Kotak 于 9 月 1 日宣布从 Kotak Mahindra 银行退休。

第一个于 2020 年退休的是阿迪亚·普里 (Aditya Puri)，他在 1990 年代离开花旗银行，创建了hdfc银行，该银行现在的市值几乎是他以前公司的两倍。第二位是今年 6 月的迪帕克·帕雷克 (Deepak Parekh)，他在 1970 年代离开大通，自己在住房金融领域建立了一个有价值的机构，然后帮助包括普里在内的其他人。最后，科塔克留下了一个在传统贷款和投资银行、资产管理和保险等领域处于领先地位的机构。他的项目的最早投资者获得了难以想象的回报：120 美元的股份在今天价值 4000 万美元。他的公司于 1992 年上市；此后其股价上涨了 12,000%。

三大巨头都在重建充满活力的私营部门方面发挥了作用。政府从 20 世纪 50 年代开始对保险公司进行国有化，随后在 1969 年至 1980 年间接管了私营银行。科塔克先生于 1985 年从商学院毕业后不久开始工作。与高盛创始人马库斯·戈德曼一样，他的第一项活动是贴现票据。科塔克以 16% 的利率借给等待塔塔集团和其他信用良好的公司付款的供应商的资金，支付了 12% 的利息。 1989年，他进入汽车金融领域。汽车供应短缺，因此成为极好的抵押品。科塔克先生安排从领先的制造商马鲁蒂铃木（Maruti Suzuki）批量购买车辆，然后在获得融资的情况下通过经销商分销这些车辆。

随着 20 世纪 90 年代印度经济的开放，科塔克先生开设了新的子公司：用于公开上市的投资银行业务，然后是保险业务，最后是 2003 年的商业银行业务。看到机遇的并不只有他一个人。 20 世纪 90 年代，印度成立了数千家金融机构，但都被 2007-09 年的全球金融危机摧毁。但科塔克先生与帕里克先生和普里先生一起，避免了根据政治和个人标准提供信贷的常见错误，并成功实现了这一目标。

Kotak Mahindra 的市值于 2021 年达到 590 亿美元的峰值。尽管增长、利润和信用质量都非常出色，但此后该数字已降至 420 亿美元。印度储备银行（ RBI ）对老板的任期实施了一项规定，这为科塔克先生的执掌生涯画上了句号。 （普里先生也遭遇了类似的命运。）科塔克先生没有把最后一天拖到最后一天，而是提前退到一边，指出他有一件大型活动要计划：他儿子的婚礼。

按照现在的要求，接替科塔克先生的两名候选人的名字已提交给印度储备银行以获得批准。中央银行行长则由总理任命。尽管明确的金融国有化时代已经结束，但一个更为安静的时代已经出现。 ■

; Thu, 07 Sep 2023 10:13:02 GMT /内容/j6r4jrfl5n02k1qm3s31re6n5el6b48c https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/09/07/the-end-of-a-remarkable-era-in-indian-finance A higher global oil price will help Russia pay for its war

财富不可能永远持续下去。尽管西方禁运、产量减少以及黑海航行的风险，近几个月来俄罗斯原油出货量达到创纪录水平，但 8 月份俄罗斯原油出货量降至每天 300 万桶，比 4 月至 5 月的平均水平低约 80 万桶，低于战前水平。他们的表现可能仍低于标准。 9 月 5 日，俄罗斯表示将把 8 月份首次宣布的“自愿”减产 30 万桶/日延长至 2023 年底（此次减产的基准尚不清楚）。

正当克里姆林宫想要补充其军事武库时，出口疲软却让其失去了财宝。根据咨询公司 Rystad Energy 的维克托·库里洛夫 (Viktor Kurilov) 的估计，8 月份来自原油销售的联邦税收收入降至 80 亿美元，低于去年 7 月份的 100 亿美元和 8 月份的 130 亿美元（见图表）。长期以来， 卢布一直是俄罗斯韧性的另一个象征，但卢布兑美元汇率已跌至近 100 美元，这是自入侵以来的最便宜水平。这两次经济衰退都让俄罗斯迫切需要从其生产的每一滴原油中赚取更多的钱。新剧本中的三种战术特点。

第一个——以销售的更少的桶来追求更高的价格——面临着困难。 1 月至 8 月期间，俄罗斯主要原油等级乌拉尔原油的平均价格为每桶 59 美元，低于去年前 8 个月的每桶 83 美元。这主要是因为全球油价下跌，同期从 104 美元跌至 81 美元。但西方的禁运也可能起到了一定作用，这使得中国和印度等其他买家更容易通过谈判压低价格。 G 7 的“价格上限”也是如此，它禁止西方托运人和保险公司为俄罗斯原油出口提供便利，除非燃料售价低于每桶 60 美元。

不过，最近，追逐更高价格的策略取得了一些成功。美国利率见顶的预期以及俄罗斯和沙特阿拉伯的减产推动全球油价上涨，9 月 5 日油价今年首次突破每桶 90 美元。这对俄罗斯有利，俄罗斯最近建立了一支“灰色”油轮船队（通常是海湾地区、香港或土耳其的不知名中介机构拥有的老化船只），以及一个国家支持的保险体系，该体系将其大部分分销网络与价格上限隔离开来。影响。它还减少了从黑海的运输量，增加了从波罗的海和远东港口的运输量，这些地方违反制裁的行为更难被发现。自 8 月中旬以来，乌拉尔原油价格一直高于每桶 70 美元。

西方不太可能推动更严格地执行其价格上限：它希望保持俄罗斯石油的流动，以避免今年晚些时候全球经济反弹时出现供应短缺。因此，乌拉尔石油价格的上涨看起来是安全的，即使很难说服客户接受相对于全球石油价格较小的折扣。印度坚称，乌拉尔原油价格上涨削弱了该等级原油的竞争优势，特别是与海湾原油相比。这有点不诚实。数据公司 Kpler 认为，尽管乌拉尔原油是一种优质混合原油，但与最便宜等级的沙特原油相比，乌拉尔原油继续以 7 美元的折扣进行交易。印度的顽固暗示它可能在谈判中占据上风。

随着俄罗斯原油销量的减少，它也在试图出售更多的优质成品油——这是其维持收益的第二个策略。为此，它可以通过炼油厂利用闲置产能加工更多原油，Kpler 估计闲置产能占总量的 10%。分析师认为，原定于本月进行的大部分维护工作将推迟到明年秋季。它正在最大限度地提高柴油这种高利润产品的产量，但却损害了航空燃油。 8月份，该国出口的此类“清洁”产品比过去六年同月的出口量都要多。

俄罗斯试图弥补原油运输量下降的第三种方式是开发新的石油分销渠道。出口商正在谨慎地增加对那些仍然可以并且确实购买俄罗斯石油的欧洲国家的管道流量：即捷克共和国和匈牙利。分析师预计这种情况将持续到 2025 年，届时捷克管道运营商应该有能力从连接其与意大利的管道中获取更多原油。

俄罗斯还开始通过北极运送更多货物，这可能会降低运往中国的成本。该航线比从波罗的海和巴伦支海出发的航线短30-45%。 Kpler 数据显示，到 2023 年，使用这条航线的俄罗斯原油油轮数量将增加八倍。北极航行只能在夏季和初秋进行，但俄罗斯押注于全球变暖，目标是到 2025 年实现全年航行。为时已晚，无法支持战争努力。在此期间决定俄罗斯出口收入的大部分因素（首先是全球经济状况）仍然超出俄罗斯的控制范围。 ■

; Wed, 06 Sep 2023 16:50:08 GMT /内容/rr2mjas9ecst8qptalv93vumh3cjg6nq https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/09/06/a-higher-global-oil-price-will-help-Russia-pay-for-its-war The $100trn battle for the world’s wealthiest people

超级富豪雇佣各种各样的人来让他们的生活更轻松。园艺师维护花园，管家整理房屋，保姆抚养孩子。然而，也许没有什么角色比财富经理更重要了，财富经理的职责是保护资本。

这些顾问分散在全球日内瓦和纽约等城市，并被聘为受托人，这意味着他们必须为客户的利益行事。因此，他们了解富人和名人的私密生活，他们必须揭露他们的秘密，以便可以就婚外情所生孩子的继承等问题提供建议。顾问还帮助家庭分配投资、藏匿现金、尽量减少税单、计划退休、安排财富传承并满足不寻常的愿望。 A Singapore-based manager recalls being told to invest a “double-digit” percentage of a family's wealth in “bloodstock horses”—steeds bred especially for racing—a term he hurriedly looked up after the meeting.

For decades wealth management was a niche service, looked down upon by the rest of finance. Now it is perhaps the most attractive business in the industry. Capital and liquidity requirements set after the global financial crisis of 2007-09 have made running balance-sheet-heavy businesses, such as lending or trading, difficult and expensive. By comparison, doling out wealth advice requires almost no capital. Margins for firms that achieve scale are typically around 25%. Clients are loyal, meaning that revenues are predictable. Competition has crushed profits in other formerly lucrative asset-management businesses, such as mutual funds. And whereas the pools of assets managed by BlackRock and Vanguard, the index- and exchange-traded-fund giants, are huge, they collect a fraction of a penny on every dollar invested. A standard fee for a wealth manager is 1% of a client's assets, annually.

Wealth management is all the more appealing because of how quickly it is expanding. The world economy has grown at a decent enough clip over the past two decades, at more than 3% a year. Yet it has been left in the dust by growth in wealth. Between 2000 and 2020 the total stock rose from $160trn, or four times global output, to $510trn, or six times output. Although much of this wealth is tied up in property and other assets, the pool of liquid assets is still vast, making up a quarter of the total. Bain, a consultancy, estimates that the pool will expand from just over $130trn to almost $230trn by 2030—meaning that a $100trn prize is up for grabs. They expect the boom to help lift global wealth-management revenues from $255bn to $510bn.

It will be fuelled by geography, demography and technology. The biggest managers are attempting to cover ever more of the globe as dynastic wealth is created in new markets. Baby-boomers are the last generation that can rely on defined-benefit pensions for their retirement; more people will have to take decisions about how their own wealth will support them. Meanwhile, software is streamlining the bureaucracy that once waylaid wealth managers, enabling them to serve more clients at lower cost, and helping firms automate the acquisition of new ones. These gains will allow big banks to serve the merely rich as well as the über-wealthy. Firms are already climbing down the rungs of the wealth ladder, from ultra-high-net-worth and high-net-worth clients, who have millions of dollars to invest, into the lives of those with just $100,000 or so.

Markus Habbel of Bain sees a comparison to the booming luxury-goods industry. Handbags were once prized for their exclusivity as much as their appearance, but have become ubiquitous on social media, with influencers touting Bottega Veneta pouches and Hermès bags. “Think about Louis Vuitton or Gucci. They have basically the same clients as [wealth managers] target and they increased from 40m [customers] 40 years ago to 400m now,” he notes. Upper-crust buyers have not been put off.

Which firms will grab the $100trn prize? For the moment, wealth management is fragmented. Local banks, such as btg in Brazil, have large shares of domestic markets. Regional champions dominate in hubs, including Bank of Singapore and dbs in Asia. In America the masses are served by specialist firms such as Edward Jones, a retail-wealth-management outfit in which advisers are paid based on commissions for selling funds. Only a handful of institutions compete on a truly global scale. These include Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase. But the two biggest are Morgan Stanley and a new-look ubs , which has just absorbed Credit Suisse, its old domestic rival. After acquiring a handful of smaller wealth-management firms over the past decade, Morgan Stanley now oversees around $6trn in wealth assets. Following its merger, ubs now oversees $5.5trn.

This patchwork is unlikely to last. “The industry is heading in a winner-takes-all direction,” predicts Mr Habbel, as it becomes “very much about scale, about technology and about global reach”. Jennifer Piepszak, an executive at JPMorgan, has reported that her firm's takeover of First Republic, a bank for the well-heeled that failed in May, represents a “meaningful acceleration” of its wealth-management ambitions. Citigroup has poached Andy Sieg, head of wealth management at Bank of America, in an effort to revamp its offering. In 2021 Vanguard purchased “Just Invest”, a wealth-technology company.

ubs and Morgan Stanley have grander ambitions. The firms' strategies reflect their contrasting backgrounds, and may in time produce a clash. Morgan Stanley competes globally but dominates in America, and is focusing on wealth services for the masses, as shown by its purchase in 2020 of e * trade , a brokerage platform. James Gorman, the bank's boss, has said that if the firm keeps increasing new assets by around 5% a year, its current growth rate, it would oversee $20trn in a decade or so.

This may be possible thanks to Morgan Stanley's existing scale. In 2009 the bank agreed to acquire Smith Barney, Citi's wealth-management arm, for $13.5bn, which helped boost margins to the low teens from 2% or so in the years before the financial crisis. Today they are around 27%, reflecting the use of tech to move into advising the merely rich. Andy Saperstein, head of the wealth-management division, points to the acquisition of Solium, a small stock-plan-administration firm, which Morgan Stanley purchased for just $900m in 2019, as crucial for building a strong client-referral machine. “No one was looking at the stock-plan-administration companies because they didn't make any money,” he says. But these firms “had access to a huge customer base and [clients] were constantly checking to see when the equity was going to vest, what it was worth and when they would have access to it.”

Swiss role

ubs is employing a more old-school approach, albeit with a global twist. Having taken over its domestic rival, the Swiss bank has a once-in-a-generation chance to cement a lead in places where Credit Suisse flourished, such as Brazil and South-East Asia. Deft execution of the merger would make the firm a front-runner in almost every corner of the globe. Thus, for now at least, the new-look ubs will focus more on geographic breadth than the merely rich.

In differing ways, both Morgan Stanley and ubs are seeking even greater scale. When clients hire a wealth manager they tend to want one of two things. Sometimes it is help with a decision “when the cost of making a bad choice is high”, says Mr Saperstein, such as working out how to save for retirement or a child's education. Other times it is something exclusively available, such as access to investments unobtainable through a regular brokerage account.

Being able to offer clients access to private funds or assets will probably become increasingly important for wealth managers. Joan Solotar of Blackstone, a private-equity giant, says that a quarter of the firm's assets already come from individuals, and most arrive via big banks. Greater scale for wealth managers means greater bargaining power when negotiating with private-markets firms to secure exclusive deals, such as private funds for customers or lower fees. Younger generations, which will soon be inheriting wealth, are expected to demand more environmentally and socially conscious options, including those that do not just screen out oil companies, but focus on investing in, say, clean energy. A decade ago a client would tend to follow their wealth adviser if he or she moved to a new firm. Exclusive funds make such a switch more difficult.

The winner-takes-all trend may be accelerated by artificial intelligence ( ai ), on which bigger firms with bigger tech budgets already have a head-start. ai could be used to create three kinds of tool. The first would take a firm's proprietary information, such as asset-allocation recommendations or research reports, and spit out information that advisers can use to help their clients. Attempts to build such tools are common, since they are the easiest to produce and pose few regulatory issues.

The second type of tool would be trained on client information rather than companies' proprietary data, perhaps even listening in on conversations between advisers and clients. Such a tool could then summarise information and create automatic actions for advisers, reminding them to send details to clients or follow up about certain issues. The third kind of tool is the most aspirational. It would be an execution tool, which would allow advisers to speak aloud requests, such as purchasing units in a fund or carrying out a foreign-exchange transaction, and have a firm's systems automatically execute that transaction on their behalf, saving time.

It will take money to make money, then. The biggest wealth managers already have hefty margins, access to products their clients want and a head start on the tech that might put them even further ahead. “We are a growth company now,” claims Mr Saperstein of Morgan Stanley, a sentence that has rarely been uttered about a bank in the past 15 years. “We are just getting started.”

Yet the two giants are both going through periods of transition. ubs has barely begun the open-heart surgery that is required when merging two large banks. Meanwhile, Mr Gorman, the architect of Morgan Stanley's wealth strategy, will retire some time in the next nine months. The succession race between Mr Saperstein, Ted Pick and Dan Simkowitz, two other executives, is already under way. Either firm could falter. Although the two are chasing different strategies, it is surely only a matter of time before they clash. ubs is on an American hiring spree; Morgan Stanley is eyeing expansion in some global markets, including Japan.

And despite the advantages offered by scale, smaller firms will be hard to dislodge entirely. Lots of different types of outfit have a foothold, from customer-directed brokerage platforms, like Charles Schwab, which also offer their richest customers advice from a fiduciary, to asset-management firms, such as Fidelity and Vanguard, which have millions of customers who might seek advice. “Back in the day, when our programme was started, it was focused on how you help people manage their wealth using mutual funds. But the business has evolved,” says Rich Compson of Fidelity. The firm's wealth arm, which oversees $1.8trn, also offers advice on ways to use individual securities, exchange-traded funds and alternative investments.

When Willie Sutton, a dapper thief also known as Slick Willie who died in 1980, was asked why he robbed banks, he replied that it was “because that's where the money is”. The aphorism helps explain strategy on Wall Street, as firms race to take advantage of the $100trn opportunity in wealth management. Once the business was a sleepy, unsophisticated corner of finance. Now it is the industry's future. ■

; Tue, 05 Sep 2023 20:03:08 GMT /content/2jg7jbi0223vhm0ecb1t0cf95c3vodtv https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/09/05/the-100trn-battle-for-the-worlds-wealthiest-people Germany’s economic model is sputtering. So are its banks

G ermany's economic model is known for close relations between bosses and unions; the Mittelstand, the country's world-leading manufacturing firms; and the political system's federalism, which spreads prosperity widely. Another ingredient is less renowned but no less fundamental: the country's banks, many regionally focused, provide long-term funding to Mittelstand companies nice and cheaply.

Unfortunately, this model is no longer delivering: German growth is forecast by the imf to be the lowest of any g 7 member this year. And the country's banks are struggling, too. The European Banking Authority estimates that in the first three months of 2023 their weighted-average return on equity, a measure of profitability, was 6.5%, compared with 10.4% across the eu . In 2020 banks in eight countries in the eu offered worse returns than German lenders. In the first three months of this year only those in Luxembourg did.

In part, this poor performance reflects quirks of the German market. The country's banks are unusually keen on making fixed-rate loans, which has limited their ability to profit from higher interest rates. Their net interest margin—what a bank collects on loans minus what it pays for funding—has grown by just 0.1 percentage points since June 2020, half the eu average.

Yet there are also deeper issues at play. German lenders are unusually structured, coming in three categories: private-sector lenders, including Commerzbank and Deutsche Bank; public banks, including 361 savings banks and five Landesbanken, which act as wholesale banks for the savings banks; and 737 co-operatives.

Non-private lenders, which hold 57% of banking-sector assets, are conservative outfits with goals besides profits, such as supporting local firms. Many public banks have politicians as chairs or board members. This politicised governance brings poor risk management, says Nicolas Véron of Bruegel, a think-tank. Lots are highly exposed to property, for instance, leaving them vulnerable to recent price falls.

Public banks and co-operatives also operate on a “regional principle” that bars them from seeking business in one another's territory. They form networks, with the biggest possessing more assets than any single European bank, allowing them to share costs and reducing the amount of capital with which they are required to fund themselves. As a result, margins for private-sector banks are squeezed, making it hard for them to compete with other institutions. Deutsche Bank's price-to-book ratio languishes at 0.3, about half that of bnp Paribas, a French rival.

Germany's unusual financial system is well-suited to supporting regional companies. It is rather less well-suited to supporting riskier business (say, startups needed for the green transition or digitisation) that require funding from capital markets alongside more traditional forms of finance. Although German politicians and policymakers are engaged in a lively debate about the country's economic future, discussion of its financial institutions has yet to feature prominently. Perhaps the country's banks are simply too much of a fixture to be questioned. ■

; Thu, 31 Aug 2023 10:21:34 GMT /content/g7nulu8ddrv1n6p1cceqb73vgnddgsrk https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/08/31/germanys-economic-model-is-sputtering-so-are-its-banks Europe’s economy looks to be heading for trouble

E urope's summer was a strange mixture of heavy rainfall and wildfires. The continent's economy was also plagued by extremes. Inflation remained hot: prices rose by 5.3% in August compared with a year earlier. And officials are increasingly worried by the cloudy growth outlook. A recent drop in the purchasing managers' index ( pmi ) suggests the bloc is facing recession.

Ahead of the next meeting of the European Central Bank ( ecb ) on September 14th, policymakers will be worried by the possible emergence of stagflation (a situation in which low growth is paired with entrenched inflation). Christine Lagarde, the central bank's president, recently reiterated her commitment to bringing down inflation and setting interest rates at “sufficiently restrictive levels for as long as necessary to achieve a timely return of inflation to our 2% medium-term target”. In plain English: the ecb would much prefer a “hard landing”, featuring economic pain, to failing to reduce price rises.

The problem is that the ecb risks crashing the plane. Euro-zone inflation is proving as stubborn as the American variety. In Europe, price rises were sparked by increasing energy costs; in America, they were more demand-driven. But in both places inflation has followed a similar path, with Europe slightly behind. Now the question is whether core inflation, which excludes volatile energy and food prices, will come in to land. So far, it is staying stubbornly high (see chart).

This is in part because Europe has, like America, so far managed to dodge recession. At the end of last year, when many expected a European downturn, monetary tightening had yet to hit the economy and national governments offered generous handouts in order to counteract the energy shock. The service sector showed decent growth, and industrial order books remained full from the post-covid boom.

Gloom is now spreading across the continent. The global economy is weakening, and order books have plenty of blank pages. State support for households is also running out. Retail energy prices remain higher than before last year's crisis; real incomes have yet to recover. Activity in the service industry contracted in August, according to the pmi survey. The sector is at its weakest in two and a half years.

Higher interest rates have also started to affect the European economy, as intended by the ecb ’s policymakers. Construction, which is traditionally sensitive to interest rates, is feeling the pain. Stingier bank lending is leading to a 0.4 percentage-point reduction in gdp growth each quarter, according to Goldman Sachs, a bank. Corporate insolvencies rose by more than 8% in the year's second quarter, compared with the first, and have reached their highest since 2015. The impact of tighter monetary policy will peak in the second half of this year, predicts Oliver Rakau of Oxford Economics, a consultancy.

A hard landing is thus almost guaranteed. But the return of inflation to the ecb ’s 2% target remains some way off. Two forces are pulling prices in different directions. One is the situation in the labour market. Unemployment remains at a record low. Although firms are hiring fewer workers, there is no imminent danger of mass lay-offs—in part because bosses want to hold on to workers that are increasingly scarce in an ageing continent. As a result, wages across the bloc are rising, even if not by enough to make up for earlier inflation.

The other force, which is pulling down inflation, is weakening demand for goods and services. During the covid pandemic, price growth took off in advance of wage growth, causing companies' profits to rise strongly alongside inflation. If companies now find that demand is drying up, it is possible that inflation will fall at the same time as wage growth stays high, bringing profits back down. Indeed, prices on wholesale markets for goods are already falling fast, and import prices are also declining. At some point, these lower prices will be passed on to consumers.

Which of these two forces will win out? At the moment, it looks like the answer will be weak demand, since it has spread to the service sector, too. This suggests that euro-zone inflation might fall in relatively short order. But the ecb appears unconvinced, and seems ready to lift its main rate to 4.5% from 4.25%. Policymakers would be better off holding rates steady, so that they can assess the danger of a crash. ■

; Thu, 31 Aug 2023 10:21:10 GMT /content/7io1r82smnlm5ge7gmo2vk1ncm8i5lia https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/08/31/europes-economy-looks-to-be-heading-for-trouble How will politicians escape enormous public debts?

T he world’s public finances look increasingly precarious. In the year to July America's federal government borrowed $2.3trn, or 8.6% of GDP —the sort of deficit usually seen during economic catastrophes. By 2025 five of the G 7 group of big rich countries will have a net-debt-to- GDP ratio of more than 100%, according to forecasts by the imf . Such debts may have been sustainable in the low-interest-rate era of the 2010s. But those days are long gone. This month the ten-year Treasury yield briefly hit 4.3%, its highest since before the global financial crisis of 2007-09.

How will governments shed these burdens? Economists are increasingly gripped by the question. A recent paper by Serkan Arslanalp of the imf and Barry Eichengreen of the University of California, Berkeley, presented at America's annual monetary-policy jamboree in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, on August 26th, sets out a menu of options. It is not exactly an appetising one.

Big economies have had big debts before. Broadly speaking, they have dealt with them by employing one of two strategies. Call them the austere and the arithmetic. The austere method is to run primary surpluses (ie, surpluses before debt-interest payments). In the 1820s, after the Napoleonic wars, Britain's debts reached almost 200% of GDP ; the Franco-Prussian war left France owing nearly 100% of GDP in the 1870s. Previously Mr Eichengreen and co-authors found that between 1822 and 1913 Britain ran primary surpluses sufficient to reduce the debt-to- GDP ratio by more than 180 percentage points; France did enough to reduce its ratio by 100 percentage points in just 17 years after 1896.

Messrs Arslanalp and Eichengreen are pessimistic about the prospect of democracies repeating the trick today. In the 19th century welfare states were minimal. British politicians followed the Victorian philosophy of “sound finance”; the French sought to reduce debts so as to be ready for their next war. In contrast, modern welfare states are weighed down by ageing populations, and the need for more defence spending and green investment means the size of the state is growing. Politicians could raise taxes. But other research by the IMF finds that in advanced economies, from 1979 to 2021, fiscal consolidations were less likely to succeed in cutting debts if they were driven by tax increases instead of spending cuts, perhaps because raising taxes harms economic growth.

What about the arithmetic approach? This was the path many countries followed after the second world war, when America's debts peaked at 106% of GDP ( a level they could soon surpass). It involved the rate of economic growth exceeding the inflation-adjusted rate of interest, such that legacy debts shrank relative to GDP over time, with small primary surpluses chipping in. It is possible to argue that recent high rates of inflation have started the world economy on the arithmetic debt-reduction route. Indeed, advanced-economy net debts have fallen by about four percentage points after shooting up in 2020 when covid-19 struck.

Yet inflation only reduces debt when it is unexpected. If bondholders anticipate fast-rising prices, they will demand higher returns, pushing up the government's interest bill. Persistent inflation helped after the second world war only because policymakers held down nominal bond yields in a policy known as financial repression. Until 1951 the Federal Reserve capped long-term rates by creating money to buy bonds. Later a ban on paying interest on bank deposits would redirect savings to the bond market.

The resulting low real interest rates were paired with rapid post-war growth. Between 1945 and 1975, this reduced the debt-to- GDP ratio by a weighted average of 80 percentage points across the rich world. Both sides of the equation were important. Everyone can agree growth is desirable—it is the “painless way of solving debt problems”, write Messrs Arslanalp and Eichengreen, and it averaged an annual 4.5% across the rich world in this period. But high growth typically raises real interest rates. Another working paper, by Julien Acalin and Laurence Ball, both of Johns Hopkins University, finds that with undistorted real interest rates and a balanced primary budget, America's debt-to- GDP ratio would have declined to only 74% in 1974, rather than the actual figure of 23%.

Unless artificial intelligence or another technological breakthrough unleashes a step change in productivity growth, today's ageing economies have no chance of matching post-war rates of expansion. America's GDP is expected to rise at an annual pace of just 2% over the next decade. That immediately limits the arithmetic strategy by putting the onus on real interest rates. There are good reasons to expect rates to be “naturally” low, such as more saving as societies age. But investors seem to be having doubts, as the recent rise in long-term bond yields demonstrates. Financial repression and high inflation to bring down real rates would require sweeping changes, such as central banks abandoning their inflation targets, as well as a reversal of much of the financial liberalisation that took place towards the end of the 20th century.

Best of the worst

What, then, will happen? “Governments are going to have to live with high inherited debts,” reckon Messrs Arslanalp and Eichengreen. The best politicians can do is not to make a bad situation worse. Yet the ongoing accumulation of debt suggests it is unlikely that politicians will follow this advice. On its current path America will match its post-war record of spending 3.2% of GDP on interest in 2030. Two decades later this will pass 6%. The bill could be higher if another pandemic or major war arrives in the meantime.

However unlikely it seems that voters and politicians will be willing to tolerate primary surpluses, sustained inflation or financial repression, they will probably reach a point where they are equally unwilling to put up with handing over a large chunk of tax revenues to bondholders. At such a time political constraints will ease—and the danger of a bond-market crisis will rise. The debt-reduction menu will then not look quite so unpalatable. ■

; Thu, 31 Aug 2023 10:00:53 GMT /content/lkdfaet038kvbaq1599anphtebsmofa6 https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/08/31/how-will-politicians-escape-enormous-public-debts Which country’s genius deserves the €200 note?

M oney can look like just about anything. In ancient China, bronze knives circulated as a means of payment; during the Depression, Californians used clamshells instead of cash; in 1970 Irish shoppers were forced, by a banking strike, to make do with iou s written on toilet paper. As Hyman Minsky, an economist, put it: “Anyone can create money; the problem is getting it accepted.”

Europeans will soon need to accept a new-look euro. A European Central Bank ( ecb ) survey, which closed at the end of August, asked respondents to choose between seven themes, varying from “hands: together we build Europe” to “rivers, the water of life in Europe” and “our Europe, ourselves”. A design contest will now follow, and updated euros will emerge from cash machines in 2026.

Economists see money as a neutral medium of exchange, but images on banknotes are some of the world's most recreated designs. For governments, they are an opportunity to put propaganda in pockets, and transmit a certain idea of the state. Birds, another possible theme, would symbolise “freedom of movement”, the ecb says, as well as celebrate the eu birds directive, which protects nature. Such a rosy picture of European co-operation is in stark contrast with the messages sent a century ago: the German 10,000 mark note, introduced in 1922, included a vampire, representing France, sucking a German worker dry.

Putting dead presidents on money, as America does, or monarchs, like Britain, is a less appealing option in Europe. A squabbling bloc of 20 countries, including those for which the term “nationalism” was coined, are unlikely to be satisfied with a focus on any one country's leaders, even those long gone. Famous artists, a mooted alternative, will almost certainly end up with an argument over which country's genius deserves the €200 note, which ends up on the €5 and which misses out altogether.

The ecb previously managed to swerve these dilemmas by using imaginary bridges. These showcased the continent's traditional architectural styles (baroque, neoclassical and so on) without favouring any single country's monuments. That was until Spijkenisse, in the Netherlands, spoiled things. The suburb of Rotterdam turned the images into reality, employing dyed concrete to match the colour of the banknotes.

Whatever the end product looks like, cash is on the way out. According to the ecb , it was used for just 59% of euro transactions last year, down from 72% three years previously. For many Europeans, especially younger ones, money no longer looks like paper or coins, but whatever a smartphone screen displays. Ultimately, then, the new look for the euro will be decided more by graphic designers in Silicon Valley than central bankers in Frankfurt. ■
